climbs.name: Woofun
climbs.fa: David Sampson, Larry Reinmuth, Chris Maker

content.description: Short sport route with a crux clearing the bulge. Fun route that is well protected with bolts.
content.location: Towards the right side of the wall, just to the left of the wide crack.

content.description: Face to crack on the far right side of the wall, to the right of "No Cats" big crack, but at this point still uses the anchors for No Cats for descent.
content.location: Far right side of the wall.

content.description: The right-hand, left arching crack of the two largest vertical cracks on the wall. Shares anchors with Hair of the Dog.
content.protection: Trad gear with 2 bolts adding protection.

climbs.name: No Cats
climbs.fa: David Sampson, Tauru Chaw, Christi Bruchok

content.description: The wide crack that separates a south facing buttress from the main wall. Can be climbed in many different ways and protected solidly with gear placed on either the left (main) wall or the right buttress while climbing. Provides very good LD trad practice and has generally very good rock.
content.protection: At least a single set of cams depending on how much gear you like to place. Bolted anchor is up and slightly right of the top of the chimney.
content.location: Far right of the wall, see the route map.

content.description: Crack located on the left side of the East-SE facing wall (just right of The Dogs..., and shares the same anchors)

Mixed face climbing on good rock with a bulge at the top situated between the two largest vertical cracks on the left hand side of the wall. Note: some poor rock at the start of this climb, which is mostly cleaned off. This climb was named for the on-sight ground-up FA being a cure for the retched hangover that AMH was suffering from that morning, after too much wine around a LD campfire. Bolts were added to reduce the runout sections.
content.protection: Trad gear with 4 bolts protecting the places where gear is tricky.

climbs.name: The Dogs Must Think We're Crazy

content.description: Blunt arête located on the left side of the East-SE facing wall. Note: 1) some poor quality rock at the bottom and top of this climb, and 2) a bit spicy near the top (i.e., bolts are > 10 feet apart).

Thin vertical crack on the right side of the East-SE facing wall. Route follows the thin vertical crack through a bulge, up to a ledge with anchors below the huge boulder sitting at the top of the formation. Single rack to 1.5 inch.
content.protection: Single rack to 2 inches. Good gear placement.
content.location: See route map, this is towards the right end of the formation.

content.description: Climb obvious crack/face to top. Use your creativity to build a gear anchor for your follower. Walk off via 4th class gully between main wall. Gear is mostly small horizontal placements.
content.protection: Single rack to 1. I used a #2, #1, and .5 for gear anchor.
content.location: On the short pillar directly behind (east of) the main wall.

content.description: Dog Town is mostly an east-facing wall with two slightly detached buttresses. Climbing is easy to moderate on relatively good rock. Despite is modest appearance from the road, it is an impressive cliff that offers fun climbing. Area gets nice morning sun and not a lot of shade during the day.
